content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see five separate pieces of tissue, likely from a colorectal cancer resection specimen, embedded in adipose tissue. Several of these pieces (top right, bottom right, top middle) appear to be lymph nodes that are heavily infiltrated and expanded by purple (basophilic) cells, highly suspicious for metastatic carcinoma. The tissue piece on the top left is different; it is less cellular and appears to contain some glandular structures mixed with adipose and fibrous tissue, which might be part of the primary tumor or surrounding soft tissue.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into the tissue fragment on the top left because it is structurally different from the other, more obvious lymph nodes. This piece contains glandular elements adjacent to fat. It is crucial to examine this area to determine if it represents the invasive front of the primary tumor extending into the pericolic soft tissue, which is a key factor for determining the T stage. I would be looking for features like the morphology of the glands, the nature of the interface with the fat, and any signs of lymphovascular or perineural invasion. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. A pathologist would zoom into this specific area because it contains a tiny, isolated, dark purple speck on the periphery of the lowest tissue fragment, which is predominantly adipose tissue. In the context of cancer staging, it is critical to investigate any small, abnormal-looking cell clusters, as they could represent isolated tumor deposits (tumor nodules in the pericolic fat) or a micrometastasis in a very small, otherwise inconspicuous lymph node. Thorough examination of the perinodal fat is essential for accurate staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the large, somewhat irregular-shaped lymph node at the bottom of the image. The specific area of interest is the periphery or the capsular region of the node. This is a critical area to examine for several reasons: 1) To check the subcapsular sinus, which is often the first site of metastasis. 2) To assess the integrity of the lymph node capsule. 3) To look for extranodal extension, which is when tumor cells break through the capsule and invade the surrounding perinodal fat. The interface between the dense lymphoid tissue and the surrounding fat in the thumbnail appears slightly irregular, warranting a closer inspection. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the lymph node at the top center of the image because it exhibits a feature highly suspicious for metastasis. At low power, there is a dense, dark aggregate of cells that appears to have an irregular, infiltrative border with the surrounding adipose tissue. This pattern suggests that tumor cells may be breaking through the lymph node capsule and invading the fat, a feature known as extranodal extension, which must be confirmed at high magnification. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the large lymph node on the right side of the image. At low power, this node appears almost entirely replaced by a dark, cellular infiltrate, losing its normal architecture (e.g., distinct cortex, medulla, and germinal centers). This is a classic appearance for a lymph node heavily involved by metastasis. The purpose of zooming in is to examine the cytology of these cells at high magnification to confirm they are malignant tumor cells and not a reactive process or lymphoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it is located at the periphery of the largest lymph node on the right. This specific region includes the lymph node capsule and the subcapsular sinus. The subcapsular sinus is the initial site where metastatic tumor cells, arriving via afferent lymphatic vessels, typically deposit and begin to proliferate. Therefore, a meticulous examination of the entire subcapsular sinus is a critical first step in ruling out or identifying nodal metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining all potential lymph nodes submitted for evaluation. The green box is centered on the smallest, most centrally located lymph node on the slide. It is crucial to examine every lymph node, regardless of its size, for micrometastases. I am zooming in to assess the architecture of this node and to carefully screen for any atypical epithelial cells that would indicate a positive lymph node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a glandular structure on the left, lined by crowded, pseudostratified columnar epithelium with hyperchromatic nuclei, which is consistent with colonic adenocarcinoma. This glandular component is surrounded by a pink, fibrous stroma. To the right, there is mature adipose tissue. The interface between the tumor/stroma and the adipose tissue in this specific field appears relatively smooth and well-demarcated. My impression is that this is the edge of the tumor, and I would need to carefully examine the entire periphery of this tissue fragment to assess for definitive invasion into the adipose tissue, which would be critical for staging.
This is ROI 2. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, there is a small, cohesive cluster of atypical cells located on the surface of fibro-adipose tissue, associated with some hemorrhage. The cells are large, with pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and irregular shapes. My impression is that this is a focus of metastatic adenocarcinoma. This finding is clinically significant and would be classified as a positive lymph node (if within a node) or a tumor deposit (if in the perinodal soft tissue), which would upstage the patient's cancer.
This is ROI 3. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the edge of a lymph node. On the lower left and lower right, there is dense lymphoid tissue composed of sheets of small, dark lymphocytes. In the center, there is mature adipose tissue (fat cells). Separating the lymphoid tissue from the fat is a band of pink, fibrous connective tissue, which represents the lymph node capsule. I do not see any atypical cells, malignant glands, or necrotic debris in the capsule or the adjacent fat in this specific field. My impression of this area is a benign lymph node capsule with adjacent perinodal adipose tissue. There is no evidence of metastatic carcinoma or extranodal extension in this particular view.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms the presence of a metastatic tumor. There is a dense, monotonous population of malignant cells that has effaced the normal lymph node architecture. Critically, these tumor cells are clearly seen infiltrating into the adjacent perinodal adipose tissue, confirming extranodal extension. The cells are atypical, with hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node with extranodal extension.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a dense, monotonous sheet of cells that have completely replaced the normal lymphoid tissue. The cells have round to oval, hyperchromatic nuclei with irregular contours, and scant cytoplasm. There is no glandular formation, suggesting a poorly differentiated or solid pattern of carcinoma. A small portion of the lymph node capsule and adjacent fat is visible at the bottom left. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, massively infiltrated by metastatic adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the edge of the lymph node. The upper portion consists of a dense, monotonous population of small, dark lymphocytes, characteristic of lymphoid tissue. On the left, there is a remnant of a lymphoid follicle. The lower portion displays the fibrous capsule of the lymph node and the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue, which contains several blood vessels. Crucially, the subcapsular sinus (the space just beneath the capsule) appears to be filled with small lymphocytes and does not contain any clusters of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or other features suggestive of metastatic carcinoma. My impression of this specific field of view is a benign/reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the interface between the lymph node parenchyma and the surrounding adipose tissue. The node is composed of a dense, uniform population of small lymphocytes, with a follicular structure visible. I do not see any atypical cells, malignant glands, or clusters of carcinoma cells within the lymphoid tissue or sinuses. My impression of this specific field of view is that it represents a benign (negative) lymph node, showing reactive changes but no evidence of metastasis.
